block.p: Thoughts of a world-renowned conductor and composer on the eve of his only daughter's wedding: "I don't worry at all when I'm conducting an orchestra, but I certainly do when I'm going to give my daughter away."
LUKAS FOSS was contemplating the prospect of escorting ELIZA FOSS, an actress, down the aisle in Manhattan this afternoon, when she marries PHILLIP TURINO, an architect.

LUKAS FOSS was contemplating the prospect of escorting ELIZA FOSS, an actress, down the aisle in Manhattan this afternoon, when she marries PHILLIP TURINO, an architect.

Mr. Foss will escort his daughter to a march from "The Marriage of Figaro," which he arranged for the occasion. Then as soon as he completes the walk, he will slip into the role of pianist for a wedding aria called "Come, My Beloved," from his cantata "Song of Songs." It is to be sung by CAROLANN PAGE, soprano.

Other musicians who will participate, both individually and collectively, are CAROL WINCENC, flute; HUMBERT LUCARELLI, oboe, and SUSAN JOLLES, harp. "The musicians are all friends, and Mozart is my friend, too," Mr. Foss said. "He has been my friend since I was 7 years old."
For the reception, he is to turn the reins over to another friend, LARRY RIVERS, the artist and jazz saxophonist, whose band will play for dancing.
"Being the father of the bride is an incredibly romantic situation," Mr. Foss said. "Maybe I had that in mind when I wrote the 'Song of Songs.' "
